abstract.para: A project is a collection of software packages maintained by a team. You can grant different rights to the team members. Users can subscribe to such a project and use it as an installation source to enhance their installed openSUSE system.

sect2.title: The openSUSE Build Service as a Project Repository
sect2.para: The openSUSE Build Service at is a platform suitable to prepare software collections for installation on a range of systems. These software collections are organized as projects and thus you can consider the Build Service as a repository of software projects.
sect2.remark: 2007-08-28 - fs: The following paragraph needs to be revised. The definition of a normal project could be more precise.
sect2.para: Inside the Build Service a subtle distinction exists between so called "home projects" and normal projects. While every maintainer owns a generic "home project" at http://build.opensuse.org/project/show?project=home:MAINTAINER, where he can work on software packages he is interested in, a normal project is meant to be a collection of packages belonging together to form a somehow connected or thematically consistent package set, ranging from single program projects such as mozilla or screen to broader collections such as ruby, GNOME:STABLE, KDE:KDE4, or even openSUSE:Factory.

sect2.title: Project Components
sect2.para: A project is maintained by one or more maintainers, who are allowed to add or remove maintainers and manage projects. You manage projects by adding or removing either packages or build repositories, for which the packages are meant to be built. Build repositories often are base distributions such as openSUSE 10.2, openSUSE Factory (the development tree of openSUSE) plus optional enhancements.
Maintainers can also assign "tags" to a project. Consider "tags" als labels, that help users to find projects belonging together in certain ways.
Build Service users (end users) can watch projects and rate them.
